text: He punawai kahe wale ke Aloha. (Love is a spring that flows freely.)
E hele me ka pu'olo. (Always take an offering with you.)
I Ka Nana No A 'Ike. (By observing, one learns.)
Ma Kahi O Ka Hana He Ola Malaila. (Where work is, there is life.)
E kūlia i ka nu'u. (Strive to reach the highest.)
Ua ola loko i ke aloha. (Love gives life within.)
Lana kakou i ka hau'oli o ha'i. (We rise by uplifting others.)
ʻO ka makua ke koʻo o ka hale. (The parent is the support that holds the household together.)
I maika'i ke kalo i ka 'ōhā. (The goodness of the taro is judged by the young plant it produces.)
Mai Pale I Ke A'o A Ka Makua. (Do not set aside the teaching of your elders.)
E Noho Iho i Ke Opu Weuweu Mai Ho'oki'ekie Ha'aha'a. (Remain among the clumps of grass and do not elevate yourself... Stay humble.)
E 'au malie i ke kai papa'u, o paki ka wai a pula ka maka. (Swim quietly in shallow water lest it splash into the eyes.)
Nānā ka maka; ho'olohe ka pepeiao, pa'a ka waha. (Observe with the eyes, listen with the ears, and shut the mouth.)
Aloha Mai No Aloha Aku. (When love is given, love naturally flows back in return.)
Ike 'Ia No Ka Loea I Ke Kuahu. (An expert is recognized by the altar he builds.)
Nīnau ka waha and hana ka lima. (Ask questions and work with the hands.)
ʻAʻohe pau ka ʻike i ka hālau hoʻokahi. (All knowledge is not taught in the same school.)
Mahalo i ka mea i loaʻa. (Be thankful for what you have.)
ʻAʻa i ka hula, waiho ka hilahila i ka hale. (When one wants to dance the hula, let bashfulness be left at home.)
Mōhala i ka wai ka maka o ka pua. (Unfolded by the water are the faces of flowers.)
E lauhoe mai na wa'a; i ke ka, i ka hoe; i ka hoe, i ke ka; pae aku i ka 'aina. (Everybody paddle the canoes together; bail and paddle, paddle and bail, and the shore will be reached.)
O na hoku no na kiu o ka lani. (The stars are the eyes of heaven.)
He ali'i ka 'āina; he kauwā ke kanaka. (The land is a chief; man is its servant.)
He 'olina leo ka ke aloha. (A joyousness is in the voice of love.)
No task is too big when done together by all.
Ho'olohe ke pepeiao nana I Kā maka hana kalima. (Listen carefully. Observe with eyes, work with the hands.)
Ua ola loko i ke aloha. (Life is an echo—what you give out comes back.)
Ola I Ka Makana Ma Ke Akua. (Life is a gift from God.)
Ke kai lipolipo polihua a Kane. (The dark-blue ocean of Kane.)
Ka manu kahea i ka wa'a e holo. (The bird that calls the canoe to sail.)
Endless is the good that I have given you to enjoy.
Lawe i ka ma'alea a ku'ono'ono. (Acquire skill and make it deep.)
Mālama kekahi i kekahi. (Take care of one another.)
E komo mai kāu māpuna hoe. (Put in your dip of the paddle.)
Kupukupu ke aloha, he aloha ka'i na kini. (Love that grows, love that leads multitudes.)
He a'ali'i ku makani mai au; 'a'ohe makani nana e kula'i. (I am a wind-resisting a'ali'i; no gale can push me over.)
O ka Pono ke hana 'ia a iho mai na lani. (Continue to do good until the heavens come down on you.)
Malama Kekahi I Kekahi. (Take care of one another.)
He lala wau no ku'u kumu. (I am a branch of my tree.)
E ola mau ka 'olelo Hawai'i. (The Hawaiian language shall live.)
Ka lā i ka Mauliola. (The sun at the source of life.)
I ulu no ka lālā i ke kumu. (The branches grow because of the trunk.)
E Aloha kekahi i kekahi. (Love one another.)
He ma'i maka'u 'Ole I ka lā kupulau. (A disease that has no fear of the spring sun—it will not be cured.)
Ke aloha pau 'ole. (Love without end.)
Kulia i ka nu'u. (Strive for the summit.)
Ua lehulehu a manomano ka 'ikena a ka Hawai'i. (Great and numerous is the knowledge of the Hawaiian people.)
He ali'i nō ka mea mālama 'āina. (One who cares for the land is truly a leader.)
E mālama pono i ka 'āina, a mālama mai ka 'āina iā 'oe. (Care for the land, and the land will care for you.)
Nana i ke kumu. (Look to the source.)
Hele no ka 'ala, hele no ka lima. (Where the path goes, so does the hand.)
Ka hana a ka makua, o ka hana no ia a keiki. (What parents do, children will do.)
Pū'ali kalo i ka wai 'ole. (Taro plants that grow in waterless places.)
Pupukahi i holomua. (Unite to move forward.)
A'ohe hana nui ke alu 'ia. (No task is too big when done together by all.)
He wahī ka mea i luna o ke kuahiwi; he nalowale ka mea i lalo o ka pali. (One can see what is on top of a hill; what is under a cliff is hidden.)
Ka makani kā'ili aloha. (The love-snatching wind.)
Maika'i ka hana a ka lima, 'ono nō ka 'ai a ka waha. (When the hands do good work, the mouth has good food to eat.)
Kokua aku, kokua mai. (Give help, receive help.)
He lei poina 'ole ke keiki. (A child is a lei never forgotten.)
I pa'a i ke one o Kakuhihewa. (To be anchored in the sands of Kakuhihewa—to be one who remains loyal to Oahu.)
Ka lā i ka leo; ka uwila i ke ano. (The sun (is manifested) in its light; man (is revealed) in his speech.)
Ua 'elepaio 'ia ka wa'a. (The canoe is marked by the 'elepaio bird—it will be unsatisfactory.)
E nihi ka hele i ka uka o Puna. (Walk carefully in the uplands of Puna.)
Ho'okahi ka 'ilau like 'ana. (Working together.)
Ua lehulehu a manomano ka 'ikena a ka Hawai'i. (Great and numerous is the knowledge of the Hawaiian people.)
He mana ko ka wai. (There is power in water.)
E kala mai. (Please forgive.)
A'a i ka hula, waiho i ka maka'u i ka hale. (Dare to dance, leave fear at home.)
O ke kahua ma mua, ma hope ke kukulu. (The foundation comes first, then the building.)
E ho'okanaka. (Be a person of worth.)
Kapu ka helu 'ana o nā pua o ke kalo. (It is taboo to count the blossoms of the taro.)
Mōhala i ka wai ka maka o ka pua. (Unfolded by water are the faces of flowers.)
He ulua kāpapa ka manō o Moanalua. (The shark of Moanalua is an ulua fish lying flat [in shallow water].)
Hō'ike'ike mai i kou mau makana lani. (Show us your heavenly gifts.)
Ka ua Kani-lehua o Hilo. (The rain of Hilo that patters on the lehua flowers.)
Kuu hoa i ka ua noe. (My companion in the misty rain.)
A'ohe lokomaika'i i nele i ke pana'i. (No kind deed has ever lacked its reward.)
Ka makani kā'ili aloha. (The love-snatching wind.)
He ipu pau 'ole ke aloha. (Love is a calabash that never empties.)
He punawai kahe wale ke aloha. (Love is a spring that flows freely.)
Ua ola loko i ke aloha. (Love gives life within.)
E aloha kekahi i kekahi. (Love one another.)
He 'olina leo ka ke aloha. (A joyousness is in the voice of love.)
Ke aloha pau 'ole. (Love without end.)
Aloha Mai No, Aloha Aku. (When love is given, love returns.)
He ipu pau 'ole ke aloha. (Love is a calabash that never empties.)
Kupukupu ke aloha, he aloha ka'i na kini. (Love that grows, love that leads multitudes.)
Ka makani kā'ili aloha. (The love-snatching wind.)
O ka'u aloha, 'a'ohe mea e ae. (My love, there is nothing else.)
Mōhala i ka wai ka maka o ka pua. (Unfolded by the water are the faces of flowers.)
O na hoku no na kiu o ka lani. (The stars are the eyes of heaven.)
He nani ke ao nei. (This world is beautiful.)
Ka ua Kani-lehua o Hilo. (The rain of Hilo that patters on the lehua flowers.)
Kuu hoa i ka ua noe. (My companion in the misty rain.)
Nā kai 'ewalu. (The eight seas—surrounding the islands.)
He nani ke kino o ke kai. (Beautiful is the body of the sea.)
I luna lilo i nā pali. (High above on the cliffs.)
Aia i ka nuku o ka lā. (There at the zenith of the sun.)
Nani ke kūkui aʻa i ka mālie. (Beautiful is the torch in the calm.)
E kūlia i ka nu'u. (Strive to reach the highest.)
Ma Kahi O Ka Hana He Ola Malaila. (Where work is, there is life.)
Ola I Ka Makana Ma Ke Akua. (Life is a gift from God.)
I Ka Nana No A 'Ike. (By observing, one learns.)
Nana i ke kumu. (Look to the source.)
E 'au malie i ke kai papa'u. (Swim quietly in shallow water.)
Maika'i ka hana a ka lima, 'ono nō ka 'ai a ka waha. (When the hands do good work, the mouth has good food to eat.)
E ho'okanaka. (Be a person of worth.)
O ke kahua ma mua, ma hope ke kukulu. (The foundation comes first, then the building.)
A'ohe lokomaika'i i nele i ke pana'i. (No kind deed has ever lacked its reward.)
E lauhoe mai na wa'a. (Let everyone paddle the canoes together.)
A'ohe hana nui ke alu 'ia. (No task is too big when done together by all.)
Pupukahi i holomua. (Unite to move forward.)
Lana kakou i ka hau'oli o ha'i. (We rise by uplifting others.)
Kokua aku, kokua mai. (Give help, receive help.)
Ho'okahi ka 'ilau like 'ana. (Working together as one.)
Mālama kekahi i kekahi. (Take care of one another.)
E Noho Iho i Ke Opu Weuweu Mai Ho'oki'ekie. (Remain among the clumps of grass and do not elevate yourself.)
I ulu no ka lālā i ke kumu. (The branches grow because of the trunk.)
He lala wau no ku'u kumu. (I am a branch of my tree.)
'O ka makua ke ko'o o ka hale. (The parent is the support that holds the household together.)
I maika'i ke kalo i ka 'ōhā. (The goodness of the taro is judged by the young plant it produces.)
He lei poina 'ole ke keiki. (A child is a lei never forgotten.)
E hele me ka pu'olo. (Always take an offering with you.)
He ali'i ka 'āina; he kauwā ke kanaka. (The land is a chief; man is its servant.)
E mālama pono i ka 'āina, a mālama mai ka 'āina iā 'oe. (Care for the land, and the land will care for you.)
He ali'i nō ka mea mālama 'āina. (One who cares for the land is truly a leader.)
He mana ko ka wai. (There is power in water.)
Mai Pale I Ke A'o A Ka Makua. (Do not set aside the teaching of your elders.)
Nānā ka maka; ho'olohe ka pepeiao, pa'a ka waha. (Observe with the eyes, listen with the ears, and shut the mouth.)
ʻAʻohe pau ka ʻike i ka hālau hoʻokahi. (All knowledge is not taught in the same school.)
Ua lehulehu a manomano ka 'ikena a ka Hawai'i. (Great and numerous is the knowledge of the Hawaiian people.)
E kala mai. (Please forgive.)
Mahalo i ka mea i loaʻa. (Be thankful for what you have.)
He a'ali'i ku makani mai au; 'a'ohe makani nana e kula'i. (I am a wind-resisting a'ali'i; no gale can push me over.)
Pū'ali kalo i ka wai 'ole. (Taro plants that grow in waterless places.)
E kuahui like i ka hana. (Let everybody pitch in and work together.)
E ola mau ka 'olelo Hawai'i. (The Hawaiian language shall live.)
Ka lā i ka Mauliola. (The sun at the source of life.)
O WAI KOU INOA? (What is the source of your living waters?)
Nīnau ka waha and hana ka lima. (Ask questions and work with the hands.)
O ka Pono ke hana 'ia a iho mai na lani. (Continue to do good until the heavens come down on you.)
Lawe i ka ma'alea a ku'ono'ono. (Acquire skill and make it deep.)
E 'ōpū ali'i. (Have the stomach of a chief.)
A'a i ka hula, waiho i ka maka'u i ka hale. (Dare to dance, leave fear at home.)
He mālama ʻāina, he mālama lāhui. (Those who care for the land, care for the nation.)
Kulia i ka nu'u. (Strive for the summit.)
He makana ke aloha. (Love is a gift.)
Moe ka hiamoe, ua ola hou mai - After sleep, life is renewed.
E moe mālie, e ala māmā - Sleep peacefully, wake light-hearted.
